g.text: Surface Temperature (ST) over India has increased by ~0.055 K/decade during 1860â€“2005 and follows
the global warming trend. Here, the natural and external forcings (e.g., natural and anthropogenic)
responsible for ST variability are studied from Coupled Model Inter-comparison phase 5 (CMIP5)
Greenhouse Gases (GHG) and Land Use (LU) are the major factors that gave rise to warming during the
century. Anthropogenic Aerosols (AA) have slowed down the warming rate. The CMIP5 projection
over India shows a sharp increase in ST under Representative Concentration Pathways (RCP) 8.5 where
it reaches a maximum of 5 K by the end of the 21
century. Under RCP2.6 emission scenarios, ST
increases up to the year 2050 and decreases afterwards. The seasonal variability of ST during the 21
century shows significant increase during summer. Analysis of rare heat and cold events for 2080â€“2099
relative to a base period of 1986â€“2006 under RCP8.5 scenarios reveals that both are likely to increase
substantially. However, by controlling the regional AA and LU change in India, a reduction in further
warming over India region might be achieved.
Global Surface Temperature (ST) has increased significantly during the last three decades. The recent report of the
showed the anthropogenic footprint on the global warming
of atmosphere and oceans, reduction in snow and ice, and increase in sea level. Climate change and variability
comprise complex interactions between natural and external forcings at different temporal and spatial scales.
However, quantifying the contribution of each component in the overall observed climate signal is very challeng-
ing. Climate models represent important tools to investigate the historical climate change due to anthropogenic
forcings. With these models and controlled simulations, it is possible to decompose the contributions from indi-
vidual factors or assess their combined effects on regional or global climate. This allows exploring the possible
causes and understanding the physical mechanisms behind climate change and variability
The World Climate Research Program (WCRP) has supported the development of the Coupled Model
Intercomparison Project (CMIP), which provides simulation from state-of-the-art global climate models.
CMIP model simulations have been used in the Assessment Reports of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate
Change (e.g., IPCC AR4 and AR5). The CMIP5 simulations include both historic (20
century) under different Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs)
different mitigation scenarios that influence the future emissions of greenhouse gasses, aerosols, ozone and
land use change. The CMIP5 experiment simulates historical changes in temperature with forcings driven by
Anthropogenic Aerosols (AA), Greenhouse Gases (GHGs), Land Use change (LU), Natural (NAT) forces (Solar
. Comparing these forcings with each other provides a
better understanding of the contributors to climate change over a particular region or location
India is one of the fastest-growing economies in the world. The annual ST has increased since the 1950â€™s,
particularly over India. Although, previous studies
have shown a clear increasing trend in mean, minimum,
and maximum temperatures over India during the last century, the contributing factors to this have not been
